title: Question 29

children: A 32-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-year history of nail changes. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is significant for plaque psoriasis in his brother. He takes no medications.
Nine of 10 fingernails are dystrophic. Nail findings are
shown
Toenails are not involved. The remainder of the skin and hair examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Nail psoriasis, which more commonly affects the fingernails than toenails, is characterized by dystrophic nails with yellow-red (oil stain) discoloration, pitting, and distal onycholysis.
The most likely diagnosis is nail psoriasis (
Option C

). Nail psoriasis is characterized by dystrophic nails with yellow-red (oil stain) discoloration caused by inflammation of the nail bed; pitting caused by inflammation of the nail matrix; and distal onycholysis (separation of nail plate from the nail bed). Other findings include nail plate thickening, distal nail plate crumbling, and splinter hemorrhages. Nail psoriasis more commonly affects the fingernails than the toenails. Nail psoriasis typically occurs in patients with psoriasis, but occasionally the nail changes may precede the skin changes. A family history of psoriasis can be helpful, as can a through physical examination looking for “hidden” areas of plaque psoriasis in the gluteal cleft, periumbilically, in the concha of the ear, and on the scalp. Nail psoriasis is strongly associated with psoriatic arthritis. Patients with psoriasis, particularly involving the nails, should be screened for psoriatic arthritis at diagnosis and follow-up.
Paronychia (
Option A
) is an infection of the nail fold. Acute paronychia is characterized by painful swelling of the nail fold, most commonly caused by
Staphylococcus aureus

. It typically affects only one nail. Chronic paronychia tends to be more insidious and involve multiple fingers. In adults, it is most often seen in those with frequent hand immersion in water. There is tender swelling in the nail folds, with missing or dystrophic cuticles. Chronic paronychia can cause ridging of the nail plate. These findings are not present in this patient, making chronic paronychia an unlikely diagnosis.
Lichen planus (
Option B

) can affect the nails in about 10% of cases. It causes nail plate dystrophy, including longitudinal roughness and ridging, nail thinning, red-streaking, and pterygium unguis formation (scarring of the proximal nail fold and matrix), as
shown
This patient's findings are inconsistent with nail lichen planus.
In patients with onychomycosis (
Option D

), the toenails are more commonly affected than fingernails. This patient's toenails are not involved. Nail pitting is not seen in onychomycosis but is present in this patient's nails. At times, it can be difficult to exclude onychomycosis by physical examination alone. In such cases, potassium hydroxide preparation, periodic acid-Schiff staining, or fungal culture is indicated.

references: Hinshaw MA, Rubin A. Inflammatory diseases of the nail unit. Semin Cutan Med Surg. 2015;34:109-16.
